Commit Message: Add ability to override access token request headers (#603)
Correspond Changelog Sentence: Add ability to override access token request headers by @JasonTolliver in link
Commit Description: Add ability to override access token request headers This moves the currently hardcoded getAccessTokenResponse into their own method.  This allows children providers to construct their own headers as needed. A perfect example of the necessity of this feature is the newer Pinterest v5 API.  In order to exchange the code for an access token, they require an Authorization header composed of a base64 encoded client_id and client_secret.  Without this change, the Pinterest Provider would need to entirely reimplement the getAccessTokenResponse method.  With this change, the Pinterest Provider could simply: php protected function getTokenHeaders() {     return array_merge(         parent::getTokenHeaders(),         [             'Authorization' => 'Basic ' . base64_encode("{$this->clientId}:{$this->clientSecret}"),         ]     ); } formatting Co-authored-by: Taylor Otwell taylor@laravel.com

Commit Message: Only use the read_user scope for GitLab by default
Correspond Changelog Sentence: Only use the read_user scope for GitLab by default (#403)
Commit Description: If the user created the application without checking any of the   scope checkboxes, GitLab will implicitly check all the boxes when   submitting the form. This can result in all scopes being granted   to the application, which is very broad. If the user created the application with only the read_user scope   being grantable to applications, Socialite will work correctly out   of the box (without requiring the user to override the scopes being   requested on the Laravel side). This closes #402.

Commit Description: This key name was incorrectly changed in link

These updates ensure we're using the latest API urls from Google and continue to provide a working app after the shutdown of the Google+ functionality in March 2019. By changing to the new v3 url for the user info retrieval, some of the keys from the response have changed. I've added the mappings to the old keys for the raw user data so nothing should break. These can be removed in v5.0 of Socialite.
It's possible for Google's API response to exclude the 'name' key in its JSON payload.

Commit Description: Change $scopeSeparator to a space in BitbucketProvider

Commit Message: Change $scopeSeparator to a space in BitbucketProvider
Correspond Changelog Sentence: Fix scope separator in Gitlab provider (#512)﻿
Commit Description: In Bitbucket's implementation of OAuth2, the space character is the delimiter for scopes. When trying to request multiple scopes, the request fails with the callback url having error_description appended to it with the value of 'Unknown scope: ', and then a comma-delimited list of scopes.  After that the listed error variable has a value of invalid_scope.
Use Illuminate's RedirectResponse instead of Symfony's

Commit Message: Use Illuminate's RedirectResponse instead of Symfony's
Commit Description: Illuminate extends Symfony's RedirectResponse with ResponseTrait, which introduces the header() method. By not using Illuminate's RedirectResponse Socialite breaks middlewares that try to add headers to every response (e.g. no-cache headers).

Cache User instance to allow $provider->user() to be called multiple times (#498)﻿
Commit Description: Google and Facebook require certain scopes to login correctly so they don't throw an error, which are included by default. However, when a user adds their own scopes, it overrides these scopes that they don't know about. This makes it merge them instead.
Replaced G+ scopes by Google Sign

Commit Message: Replaced G+ scopes by Google Sign
Commit Description: When using Google Sign-in, using G+ is unnecessary and can be blocked with Google Apps. Google+ can be disabled on Google Apps domains, or when enabled, it forces the user to subscribe to G+.
Replaced G+ by OpenID in scopes
Finally, OpenID isn't necessary. These scopes are enough for Google Sign-In

Commit Message: Add setting custom request parameters to redirect
Correspond Changelog Sentence: Add ability to override access token request headers by @JasonTolliver in link
Commit Description: Many popular OAuth2 providers accept custom request parameters in order to change the behavior of the authentication flow. This change adds the ability to add on arbitrary custom parameters to the initial OAuth request. The use is similar to that of the `scopes' functionality: $provider     ->scopes(['email'])     ->parameters(['key' => 'value'])     ->redirect();

Commit Description: Graph API v2.4 requires a fields parameter to return anything beyond id, name, and avatar. This fix sets the default fields to match the default scope request and common user mapping (first_name, last_name, email). Also allows custom fields to be requested instead via the fields() method.

Correspond Changelog Sentence: Include grant_type=authorization code in token request parameters (#488)﻿
Commit Description: This makes it a bit easier to add any additional parameters needed for building the auth url in a provider. For example, in Facebook you could often have the need to send the "auth_type" parameter for forcing rerequests and reauthentications: // FacebookProvider protected function getCodeRequestParameters($state) {     return array_merge(parent::getCodeRequestParameters($state), ['auth_type' => 'rerequest']); }
